unnormalised: So, you're thinking about cracking the IIT-JEE, huh? Or maybe NEET is your Everest? Welcome to the world of coaching classes, where sleep is a luxury and chai is your best friend. Let's be honest, prepping for these exams is like trying to understand why your phone has 256 GB of storage when you mostly use it for WhatsApp. Overkill, much?
normalised: So, you're thinking about cracking the I-I-T-J-E-E, huh? Or maybe N-E-E-T is your Everest? Welcome to the world of coaching classes, where sleep is a luxury and chai is your best friend. Let's be honest, prepping for these exams is like trying to understand why your phone has two hundred and fifty six gigabytes of storage when you mostly use it for WhatsApp. Overkill, much?

unnormalised: My cousin, Ramesh, bless his soul, spent 2 years at 'Vision Institute' in Kota. He emerged looking like he’d aged a decade, surviving on Maggi and the sheer will to not disappoint his parents. The guy could recite quadratic equations in his sleep, but couldn’t remember to water his tulsi plant. Priorities, Ramesh, priorities!
normalised: My cousin, Ramesh, bless his soul, spent two years at 'Vision Institute' in Kota. He emerged looking like he’d aged a decade, surviving on Maggi and the sheer will to not disappoint his parents. The guy could recite quadratic equations in his sleep, but couldn’t remember to water his tulsi plant. Priorities, Ramesh, priorities!

unnormalised: These coaching centers, man! They're like the Bollywood of education - dramatic, intense, and occasionally, completely over the top. You've got your "Super 30" types, promising miracles with just enough chalk dust and motivational speeches. Then you’ve got the corporate giants, boasting about "proven methodologies" and "personalized learning," which basically means they'll sell you different-sized textbooks.
normalised: These coaching centers, man! They're like the Bollywood of education - dramatic, intense, and occasionally, completely over the top. You've got your "Super thirty" types, promising miracles with just enough chalk dust and motivational speeches. Then you’ve got the corporate giants, boasting about "proven methodologies" and "personalized learning," which basically means they'll sell you different-sized textbooks.

unnormalised: The schedule itself? Brutal. Wake up at 6 AM, face the dawn with a physics problem, stumble through classes until 8 PM, followed by doubt-clearing sessions (which, let's be real, usually involve the teacher muttering incomprehensibly). And if you even *think* about Netflix, be prepared for the wrath of your parents, your teachers, and possibly your own conscience.
normalised: The schedule itself? Brutal. Wake up at six A-M, face the dawn with a physics problem, stumble through classes until eight P-M, followed by doubt-clearing sessions (which, let's be real, usually involve the teacher muttering incomprehensibly). And if you even think about Netflix, be prepared for the wrath of your parents, your teachers, and possibly your own conscience.

unnormalised: But hey, it's not all doom and gloom! You'll make friends, bond over shared suffering, and develop an unparalleled ability to cram information into your brain like it's a suitcase about to burst. You’ll learn to survive on 4 hours of sleep, and maybe, just maybe, you'll figure out that elusive concept of organic chemistry. I hear some students at 'Brilliant Tutorials' use mnemonics based on Bollywood songs to remember chemical reactions. Desperate times, desperate measures!
normalised: But hey, it's not all doom and gloom! You'll make friends, bond over shared suffering, and develop an unparalleled ability to cram information into your brain like it's a suitcase about to burst. You’ll learn to survive on four hours of sleep, and maybe, just maybe, you'll figure out that elusive concept of organic chemistry. I hear some students at 'Brilliant Tutorials' use mnemonics based on Bollywood songs to remember chemical reactions. Desperate times, desperate measures!

unnormalised: Speaking of desperation, let's talk mock tests. Oh, the horror! Three hours of pure, unadulterated exam pressure, designed to make you question your life choices. Scoring less than 50%? Time to start considering alternative career paths, like becoming a chaiwala (no offense to chaiwalas; it's a perfectly respectable profession). Some centers guarantee a score of >160 in NEET with consistent attendance and performance.
normalised: Speaking of desperation, let's talk mock tests. Oh, the horror! Three hours of pure, unadulterated exam pressure, designed to make you question your life choices. Scoring less than fifty percent? Time to start considering alternative career paths, like becoming a chaiwala (no offense to chaiwalas; it's a perfectly respectable profession). Some centers guarantee a score of greater than one hundred and sixty in N-E-E-T with consistent attendance and performance.

unnormalised: So, is it worth it? Well, that depends. Are you willing to sacrifice your social life, your sleep, and your sanity for a shot at IIT or AIIMS? If the answer is yes, then buckle up, buttercup. The journey will be tough, but the chai will be strong, and who knows, maybe you'll emerge victorious with a rank under 1000.
normalised: So, is it worth it? Well, that depends. Are you willing to sacrifice your social life, your sleep, and your sanity for a shot at I-I-T or A-I-I-M-S? If the answer is yes, then buckle up, buttercup. The journey will be tough, but the chai will be strong, and who knows, maybe you'll emerge victorious with a rank under one thousand.

unnormalised: Just remember, even if you don't make it, life goes on. You can always blame the coaching center (just kidding... mostly). The most important thing is to learn something along the way, even if it's just how to survive on instant noodles and endless cups of ₹10 chai from the corner shop. Good luck, and may the odds be ever in your favour!
normalised: Just remember, even if you don't make it, life goes on. You can always blame the coaching center (just kidding... mostly). The most important thing is to learn something along the way, even if it's just how to survive on instant noodles and endless cups of rupee ten chai from the corner shop. Good luck, and may the odds be ever in your favour!
